A newborn child was noted to have a congenital anomaly as shown in the image below. All ofthe following statements are true about this condition except:

options.A: Closure of abdominal wall should be done within the first year
options.B: Bilateral inguinal hernia is seen in males

questions.explanation: The congenital anomaly seen in the above image is exstrophy of the bladder (ectopia vesicae). It isassociated with epispadias, not hypospadias.Bladder exstrophy refers to herniation of the urinary bladder through an anterior abdominal walldefect. The bladder is open and exposed on the outside of the abdomen. The male to female ratiois 4:1. Chronic exposure of the bladder to the external environment can lead to adenocarcinoma ofthe bladder.The clinical features of bladder exstrophy include:•Separation of the pubic bones with non-united symphysis pubis•⚫ Epispadias925•In males: Broad and short penis and bilateral inguinal hernia• In females: Bifid clitorisManagement involves a staged surgical reconstruction of the bladder and genitalia. Closure of theabdominal and bladder wall is done in the first year of life. This often requires an iliacosteotomy to relax the tension on the bladder and repair the abdominal wall duringwound-healing.Later, reconstruction of the bladder neck, sphincters, epispadias, and other genital defects isdone.

questions.question: 916A young girl presents with continuous dribbling of urine but she voids normally. Her parentstell you that she had never been totally dry since her birth. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario with continuous dribbling of urine, in spite of regular voiding, issuggestive of an ectopic ureter.Ectopic ureter is a congenital anomaly that occurs as a result of abnormal caudal migration of theureteral bud during its insertion into the urinary bladder. They are usually associated with duplexureters and drain from the upper pole of the kidney.It is more common in females. The ectopic ureter usually opens into the urethra, vagina, andperineum. Hence, female patients present with constant urinary dripping all day, even though thechild voids regularly (Paradoxical incontinence). It can cause hydroureteronephrosis andrecurrent UTI.In males, the ectopic ureter opens always above the external urethral sphincter. Hence they areusually continent. However, it can cause other complications such as orchitis and epididymitis.Management involves re-implantation of the ureter into the bladder to treat incontinence andpreserve renal functions. If the kidney is severely affected, partial nephrectomy is helpful.

questions.question: During a cricket match, a batsman controls his urge to urinate as he is unable to take a breakin-between. While batting, he suffers a sudden blow as the ball hits him in the suprapubicregion. He presents to the emergency department with severe hypogastric pain and theinability to pass urine. He collapses suddenly during the examination. What is the most likelydiagnosis?

options.D: Pubic diastasis with bulbar urethra rupture

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario with a history of injury to a full bladder, inability to pass urine, andsyncope are suggestive of intraperitoneal rupture of the bladder.Bladder rupture can be of two types:Pubic diastasis refers to the separation of the pubic symphysis without concomitant fracture.Pubic diastasis with bulbar urethra rupture usually occurs due to straddle injury and presentswith blood at the tip of the meatus.CauseExtraperitoneal ruptureMore common (80%)Penetrating traumaPelvic fractureSurgical damageAssociated withproximal urethral injuryIntraperitoneal ruptureLess common (20%)Direct blow or fall on adistended bladder926Clinical featuresTreatmentExtraperitoneal rupturePelvic urinoma(encapsulatedcollection of extravasated urine) is seenBlood at the tip ofthe meatusCatheter drainage for 7-10 daysIntraperitoneal ruptureSudden severe pain in the hypogastriumSyncopePeritonitiSLaparotomyRepair of bladderBladder drainage

questions.question: A patient was rushed to the casualty after sustaining a suprapubic injury. On examination, noblood is seen at the meatus. On inserting Foley's catheter, gross hematuria is noted. His vitalsare stable and his pelvic X-ray is given below. What will be the next step in the managementof this patient?917
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a bladder injury. Open book fracture is most likelysuggestive of an intraperitoneal bladder injury. CT cystogram will be the next step in themanagement to confirm the type of bladder injury. In unstable patients, a cystogram will be theinvestigation of choice.If an associated urethral injury is suspected, retrograde urethrogram (RGU) is done.Management of bladder injuryNo blood at thetip of the meatusPass urethralcatheterNo hematuriaObservationNo extravasationObservationIntraperitonealruptureLaparotomyRepair of bladderBladder drainageSuspected bladder injuryHematuriaCT cystogram/CT urography©MARROWBlood at the tipof the meatusRetrogradeurethrogramUrethral rupturewith extravasationSurgicalmanagementExtravasationExtraperitonealruptureCatheter drainagefor 7-10 daysNote: Closed book pelvic fractures are more commonly associated with urethral injuries thanbladder injuries.

questions.question: An elderly man was rushed to the casualty at midnight with complaints of severe suprapubicpain and inability to pass urine for the past 24 hours. The abdominal examination finding ofthe patient is given below. A smooth and enlarged prostate was felt in the per-rectalexamination. While attempting to insert a 16-F Foley catheter in this patient, you feelresistance and fail to catheterize. What will be the next step in the management?918

options.B: Insert a smaller sized Foley catheter

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute retention of urine, possibly because of benignprostatic hyperplasia (BPH). The next step would be to insert an 18-Fr Coudé catheter.In men, the BPH especially the middle lobe enlargement obstructs the insertion of Foley'scatherter. Hence, a Coude catheter is advised over suprapubic catetherization as the immediatenext step as larger Fr Coude catheter is helpful in negotiating past the angulation in the prostaticurethra.927(Note: In acute urine retention, urethral strictures should be suspected when there is resistance atthe urethral meatus as the strictures are more common in distal urethra than proximal urethra)Bladder outlet obstruction is usually the most common cause of acute retention of urine. Itsclinical features include:•Inability to pass urine• Severe suprapubic pain• A distended, palpable, and tender bladderAcute urinary retention is managed by placing a urethral catheter as early as possible. Usually inBPH, smaller catheters will not pass through the angulation of the prostatic urethra as they areflexible and kink. Hence in BPH, the Coudé-tip catheter, which has a rigid and angulated tip, canbe used to overcome the urethral obstruction.If urethral catheter placement is not successful, suprapubic catheterization should be done.If there is a urethral stricture, a council tip catheter is used to dilate it using a cystoscope, guidewires, and urethral dilators.Urinary catheterStraight tip catheterMARROWCoude tip catheterOMARROW

questions.question: You are asked to remove a Foley's catheter after a procedure but you are unable to deflate theballoon. The surgeon himself tries to remove it after cutting the sidearm but is unsuccessfulas well. What should be the next step of management?

options.A: CT-guided rupture of bulb of Foley's
options.B: Inject ether to dissolve the balloon and pull it out
options.C: Inject water to over distend the balloon until it bursts and remove the catheter
options.D: Inflate with 20ml of water and under USG guidance, locate and prick the balloon

questions.explanation: USG-guided rupture of the balloon percutaneously after inflating it with 20ml water should be thenext step of management.The failure of the balloon to deflate may be caused by:•Faulty valve mechanism• Blockage of the inflation channel by debris•Crystallization of the fluid within the balloon (when saline is used)The next best step in the management of a retained Foley's catheter is to further inflate theballoon with 20mL of water, following which the inflated balloon is ruptured percutaneously with928a needle under USG guidance.A suprapubic approach is used in males, while in females, either a transurethral or transvaginalroute can be used. A cystoscopy should be done to ensure that all fragments are removed.Other methods of approach include cutting the sidearm of the catheter, thereby disabling thevalve mechanism, or advancing a ureteric stylet or fine-gauge wire through the inflation port todislodge debris or puncture the balloon. But these are often unsuccessful.Option A: CT is not routinely used in most settings with retained Foley's.Option B: Injection of ether through the balloon port causes the rupture of the balloon withinseconds. But this technique causes significant bladder irritation.Option C: Balloons should not be overinflated until they rupture. This may cause severe pain andcould cause bladder rupture.

questions.question: In the given picture of a Foley's catheter, what is the function of the tube marked 'A'?
questions.explanation: The given image shows a three-way Foley's catheter. The tube marked 'A' is used for continuousirrigation of the bladder to remove debris & blood clots. This is most commonly used afterany prostate surgery or conditions with bleeding in the bladder.The central tube is used for the drainage of urine and the tube on the right is used for inflating theballoon.

questions.question: What is the earliest sign seen on cystoscopy in a patient suspected to have bladdertuberculosis?
questions.explanation: The earliest sign of tuberculosis of the bladder observed by cystoscopy is the pallor of the mucosaaround the ureteric orifice due to submucous edema. Subsequently, tubercles may be seen.In long-standing cases, there is marked fibrosis and the capacity of the bladder is greatly reduced(thimble bladder). This is managed by augmentation cystoplasty.The following X-ray KUB shows a thimble bladder:929Ureteric lesions can also be seen in genitourinary tuberculosis. They include:• Kerr's kink - kinking of the ureteropelvic junction (UPJ)• Ureteral stricture• Beaded ureter• Shortening of the ureter• Golf hole ureter - Longitudinal fibrosis leading to shortening of the ureter and pulling up theorifice as a gaping hole. Reimplantation of ureter is done.Tuberculosis of the urinary tractMoth eatencalyx.Parenchymalcalcification.CorticalscarringCaseousmassHiked-uppelvisCentralpapillarynecrosisBeaded ureterRRCortical abscesswith rupture into theperinephric spaceUreteralstricture

questions.question: A 50-year-old man comes with complaints of hematuria and difficulty in urination for thepast few weeks. Microscopic examination of urine samples shows parasitic eggs as shown inthe image. Which type of bladder carcinoma is the patient most likely to develop?8
questions.explanation: MARROWThickened bladder wall(Thimble bladder)Urethral stricture930The given clinical scenario is suggestive of schistosomiasis. The patient is most likely to developsquamous cell carcinoma as it is associated with schistosomiasis. The image shows oval-shapedeggs with the terminal spine which is characteristic of Schistosoma haematobium.Schistosomal bladder cancers can also be adenocarcinoma or transitional cell carcinoma (lessfrequently).Primary bladder tumors usually originate from the transitional epithelium of the bladder (90%).Sometimes, they arise from connective tissue. Secondary tumors of the bladder arise from thesigmoid and rectum, the prostate, the uterus, or the ovaries.Carcinoma of the bladder & associated risk factors:Histological subtypeTransitional cell carcinoma (urothelial)Squamous cell carcinomaAdenocarcinomaRisk factorsSmoking Exposure to anilinedyesCyclophosphamidePelvic irradiationSchistosomiasisChronic irritation caused by stone diseaseBladder diverticulaChronic UTISmokingPersistent urachus or trigoneof the bladder

questions.question: 920Which of the following drugs causes carcinoma bladder?
questions.explanation: Cyclophosphamide (an alkylating agent) causes bladder cancerThe risk of bladder cancer with cyclophosphamide is directly proportional to the duration andintensity of cyclophosphamide treatment. Phosphoramide mustard is the primary mutagenicmetabolite that causes bladder cancer in patients exposed to cyclophosphamide.•Painless, gross hematuria is the most common symptom that is indicative of a bladder carcinomauntil proven otherwise.Depending upon the depth of invasion, bladder carcinoma can be divided intoFlat, non-invasive carcinoma in situ (CIS)• Non-muscle invasive bladder cancer (70% of cases) - does not invade detrusor muscle but caninvade lamina propria.• Muscle-invasive bladder cancer-invades the detrusor muscle.Diagnosis is by cystourethroscopy (directly visualizing the growth) and biopsy. Management is asfollows:•Non-muscle invasive bladder cancer:•• Transurethral resection of bladder tumor (TURBT) followed by intravesical chemotherapy withmitomycin C or epirubicin931• Immunotherapy with regular intravesical instillations of Bacille Calmette Guerin (BCG) inhigh-risk tumors.• Muscle invasive bladder cancer: Radical cystectomy along with urinary diversion procedure andlymph node dissection +/- neoadjuvant chemotherapyOther options:Option B: Cisplatin is an anticancer drug used to treat testicular cancer. It is associated with anincreased risk for acute myeloid leukemia (AML).Option C: Taxane is an anticancer drug and is the main component in the treatment regimens ofmetastatic cancers. Taxane's adverse effects are neutropenia and fluid retention (pulmonaryedema).Option D: Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) and is used in thetreatment of estrogen-dependent breast cancer. Due to its partial agonistic activity, it is known toincrease endometrial cancer in post-menopausal women.

questions.question: Identify the incorrect statement regarding bladder carcinoma.

options.A: Painless hematuria is the most common symptom
options.B: Inactivation of the Rb gene is implicated in the cancer formation
options.D: The most important prognostic factor is the size of the tumor

questions.explanation: The most important prognostic factor in bladder carcinoma is the depth of invasion.Activation of oncogenes such as ras, c-erbB, E2F3, and inactivation of tumor-suppressor genessuch as p53, p21, p16, and Rb gene is implicated in the cancer formation of the bladder.Clinical features of bladder carcinoma include:• Painless gross haematuria - Most common symptom and is indicative of a bladder carcinomauntil proven otherwise•Urinary retention• Constant pelvic pain• Increased urinary frequency•• Discomfort while urinating• If there is nerve involvement, pain is referred to the suprapubic region, groins, perineum, andthighs.Investigations done for bladder cancer are:•• Urine cytology - Low sensitivity• Intravenous urography - Not frequently used nowadays. Replaced by non-contrast CT and MRI• Cystourethroscopy and biopsy - The best investigation

questions.question: What is the treatment of choice for a patient with non-invasive bladder carcinoma of stagepT1?

options.C: Transurethral resection of the bladder tumor

questions.explanation: Since the pathological staging of the tumor is given (pT1), it implies that transurethral resection ofthe bladder tumor (TURBT) has already been done. Therefore, this patient should be managed932by instillation of intravesical BCG.TURBT is done for the pathologic staging of the tumor. This staging helps us to decide the furtherplan of treatment. Intravesical therapy (using chemotherapy or immunotherapy) is done within24hrs of TURBT in order to kill any residual cancer cells. It only affects the lining of the bladderand is not useful for cancers that have spread into the deeper layers.pT stage: Pathological stageTreatment of carcinoma bladder:M-VAC chemotherapy regime consists of:• Methotrexate• Vinblastine••AdriamycinCisplatinPT staExtent of the tumorgeTxToTaTisT1T2T3T4Primary tumor cannot be assessedNo evidence of primary tumorNoninvasive papillary carcinomaCarcinoma in situTumor invades subepithelialconnective tissue (lamina propria)Tumor invades muscularis propria bladder wallTumor invades perivesical tissueTumor invades any of the following: Prostate, uterus, vagina, pelvic wall and abdomina1 wallPT stageLow-grade pTaHigh-grade pTapTispT1TreatmentIntravesical chemotherapywith mitomycin, thiotepa, and adriamycin may be started after TURBTIntravesical BCGis started after TURBT933PT stagePT2PT3PT4TreatmentRadical cystectomyfollowed byradiotherapyNeoadjuvant chemotherapy (M-VAC), radical cystectomy,and radiotherapy

questions.question: A patient with carcinoma in situ of the urinary bladder is posted for intravesical therapy.What is the strain of mycobacteria that will be used in this therapy?
questions.explanation: An attenuated strain of Mycobacterium bovis is used in intravesical BCG therapy.Intravesical BCG is used for the treatment of non-invasive (no invasion into the muscle layer)urinary bladder tumors. It induces a strong local inflammatory response against the attenuatedbacteria, which helps in the destruction of the tumor cells.Option d: Mw vaccine for multibacillary leprosy patients and their contacts is extracted fromMycobacterium indicus pranii. questions.question: 921Which laser is preferred for performing transurethral resection of the bladder tumor?
questions.explanation: The Nd:YAG laser is preferred for the resection of minimally invasive bladder tumors.

questions.question: An elderly man on follow-up for treatment of bladder cancer presents with painlesshematuria. Which of the following assays should be done on this patient?
questions.explanation: An NMP 22 assay should be done in this patient to detect the recurrence of bladder carcinoma.NMP 22 is a nuclear matrix protein that is used to form cell nuclei. It is shed into the urine andhas a higher concentration in the urine of bladder cancer patients. NMP-22 cutoff levels forbladder cancer detection is > 10 units/mL.

questions.question: Urinary diversion is indicated in all the following clinical conditions, except:
questions.explanation: Urinary diversion is not done in cases of bladder hematoma.Urinary diversion procedures are performed to divert urine from the bladder to a new exit site. Itis of two types:•Cutaneous urinary diversion (External diversion): Urine drains through an opening created inthe abdominal wall and skin• Ileal conduit - urine is diverted by implanting ureters into a loop of ileum that is led out throughthe abdominal wall.934• Cutaneous ureterostomy - ureters are directed through the abdominal wall and attached to anopening in the skin.• Continent urinary diversion (Internal urinary diversion): A portion of the intestine is used tocreate a new reservoir for urine. The internal pouch is placed inside the abdomen. The ureters areattached to the internal pouch, and the internal pouch is attached to the urethra or to a stoma inthe abdomen with a valve.Indications of urinary diversion:●•• Post cystectomyCarcinoma of the urinary bladder• Distal obstruction• Neurogenic bladder•Ectopia vesicae, Incurable fistula• Irremovable obstruction• Trauma to the ureters and urethraUrinary Diversion ProceduresStoma(external)Stoma(external)Stoma(external)lleal conduitCutaneous ureterostomyCutaneous urinary diversionNeobladderContinent urinary diversionOMARROWDivertedureterHealsegmentDivertedureterDiverteduretersHeal pouch(internal)

questions.question: A patient presents to the emergency department with confusion and drowsiness. Heunderwent cystectomy with urinary diversion for bladder carcinoma 8 weeks back. ABGanalysis and electrolyte values are given below. Which of the following urinary diversionconduits was most likely done in this patient?
questions.explanation: A uretero-sigmoid diversion was most likely done in this patient as it frequently results inhyperchloremic hypokalemic acidosis. Hypokalemia is less common with ileal diversions becausethe ileum reabsorbs some of the potassium from the urine while the colon does not.The order in which the hyperchloraemic hypokalemic acidosis occurs is sigmoid colon >colon/ileum.Electrolyte abnormalities based on the part of intestine involved:935StomachHypokalemiaHypochloremiaMetabolic alkalosiJejunumHyperkalemiaHypochloremiaMetabolic acidosiIleum/colonHypokalemiaHyperchloremiaMetabolic acidosiSSSUrinary Diversion ProceduresStoma(external)Stoma(external)Ileal conduitGutaneous uroterostomyCutaneous urinary diversionNeobladderContinent urinary diversionOMARROWDivertedUreterDivertedDiverteduretors(internal).

questions.question: A 35-year-old lady experiences increased frequency of urination and lower abdominal painwhich is relieved by micturition. Urinalysis is normal. Cystoscopy reveals fissures andpunctate hemorrhages in the bladder mucosa. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario with normal urinalysis and cystoscopy findings are suggestiveof interstitial cystitis.Interstitial cystitis is a persistent, painful form of chronic cystitis, occurring most frequently inwomen. It is also known as chronic pelvic pain syndrome or bladder pain syndrome. Its clinicalfeatures include:• Severe suprapubic pain•Urinary frequency•Urgency• Hematuria• Dysuria without evidence of bacterial infectionCystoscopic findings seen in bladder mucosa are:• Fissures• Punctate hemorrhages (glomerulations)•• Ulcerations in the fundus of the bladder (Hunner's ulcer)The image shows Hunner's ulcer seen in interstitial cystitis:936Treatment options include:• Conservative - Patient education about the chronicity of the condition, behavioral modification(timed voiding, bladder training), stress reduction, dietary alteration (avoidance of caffeine andspicy and acidic foods) and physical therapy should be the initial management for all patients.• Pharmacological - Neuropathic analgesics (e.g. amitriptyline, pregabalin) are used for those witha significant pain component, whereas antimuscarinics and ẞ3-agonists are used for frequency,nocturia and urgency symptoms.•-Surgical For those with Hunner lesions, fulguration or laser to these lesions can be beneficial.Cystodistension as a treatment has variable evidence for success. If these options fail to improvesymptoms major surgical reconstruction can be considered in selected cases.Option b: Malakoplakia is a distinct form of inflammatory reaction seen in chronic cystitis. Itappears as soft, yellow, slightly raised mucosal plaques.Option d: Cystitis cystica occurs due to chronic irritation of the bladder mucosa. Cystoscopyreveals cystic lesions in the bladder.

questions.question: A child with recurrent urinary tract infection undergoes voiding cystourethrogram. It showsreflux of urine into the pelvis and calyces, without dilation of the ureter. What is the grade ofvesicoureteric reflux?
questions.explanation: Reflux of urine into pelvis and calyces without dilatation is Grade II vesicoureteric reflux (VUR).VUR is the retrograde flow of urine from the bladder to the upper urinary tract. VUR is a commonclinical entity. The investigation of choice for VUR is micturating cystourethrogram (MCU).VUR is graded as follows:GRA DESCRIPTIONDEIReflux into a non-dilated ureter937Minorcalyx-Papilla-Fornix-GRA DESCRIPTIONDEIIIIIIVReflux into the pelvis and calyces without dilatation of theureterReflux is associated with mild to moderate dilatation of the ureter, renal pelvis, and calyces, with minimal bluntingof the fornicesModerate ureteral tortuosityand dilatation of the pelvis and calycesVGross dilatation of the ureter,pelvis, and calyses; loss of papillary impressions; ureteraltortuosityGrades of vesicoureteric refluxNormal-MajorcalyxUreterRenalpelvisBladderGrade EVesicoureteriorefluxVUR into the non-dilated ureterRRBUCHng ofGrade II:VUR into the non-dilated ureter,renal pelvis and calycesGrade III:VUR into the dilated ureter and/orblunting of calyceal fornices.RRGrade IV:VUR into the grossly dilated ureterwith blunting of calyceal fornicesGrade VMassive VUR, with significantureteral dilatation and tortuosity.and loss of papillary impression.OMARROW

questions.question: Which of the following will be seen in a patient with Marion's disease?

options.A: Hypertrophy of the internal sphincter of the bladder
options.B: Hypertrophy of the external sphincter of the bladder
options.C: Congenital obstruction of the prostatic urethra

questions.explanation: Hypertrophy of the internal sphincter of the bladder is seen in Marion's disease. This leads tobladder outlet obstruction. Its clinical features include voiding and storage symptoms (usuallyassociated with BPH). Therefore it is also called prostatism sans prostate:• Increased urinary frequency•Urgency• Dribbling of urine•Hesitancy• Intermittent stream938• NocturiaIt is commonly seen in young patients.Bladder outlet obstruction can occur due to 2 causes:•Muscular causes•Congenital hypertrophy of internal sphincter, i.e., Marion's disease•• Dyssynergic contraction of the smooth muscle of the bladder neck (bladder neck dyssynergia)• Fibrosis of bladder neck following transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP)

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding the condition shown below?923DC

options.A: Bilateral in more than 50% of the cases
options.D: Affects males more often than females

questions.explanation: The given intravenous urography (IVU) image depicts cobra head/adder head deformity which is aclassic sign of ureterocele. It is associated with dysplastic renal tissue.Ureterocele:A ureterocele is the cystic enlargement of the intramural ureter. It is thought to be caused due toureteric orifice atresia. It is observed more in females than males in a 4:1 preponderance andis bilateral in about 10% of the cases. They are similar to ectopic ureters wherein the upper pole ofthe kidney is drained. This condition is typically associated with dysplastic and non-functionalrenal tissue.Clinical presentation:•Children with ureterocele usually present with infection.• Adults present with renal stones.Diagnosis:• IVU shows a classical cobra head sign but is relatively infrequently performed these days..Cystoscopy shows a bulging, translucent swelling involving the ureteric orifice where there isurinary stasis. It is emptied by ureteric peristalsis.Treatment:•Surgical excision with re-implantation of the ureter is the treatment of choice for simpleureterocele.• Renal stones associated with ureterocele are removed using an endoscopic incision• An advanced disease that causes hydronephrosis or pyonephrosis is an indication fornephrectomy.

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding bladder stone is false?

options.A: Primary bladder stone develops in sterile urine
options.C: Uric acid stones occur in patients with ileostomies
options.D: Triple phosphate calculus occurs in urine infected with urea-splitting organisms

questions.explanation: A cystine calculus occurs only in the presence of cystinuria and is radioopaque because of its highsulfur content.939Primary bladder stone:• Develops in sterile urine in the absence of any known functional, anatomic, or infectious factorsand does not necessarily imply that stones have formed de novo in the bladder.• Most common in children younger than 10 years of age• Most vesical calculi are mixed.• Ammonium acid urate, calcium oxalate, uric acid, and calcium phosphate are the most commoncomponents of primary bladder calculiSecondary bladder stone: Forms during infection, due to bladder outflow obstruction, impairedbladder emptying, or the presence of a foreign body.Types:• Calcium oxalate stones-• Uric acid stones occur in patients with gout but are also observed in patients with ileostomiesor with bladder outlet obstruction•Cystine stones - in cystinuria••Triple phosphate stones - occur in urine infected with urea-splitting organisms940
